title: Before 1 January 2018, will the U.S. Senate expand the scope of matters for which a filibuster cannot be used?
preds: Because it will come back to haunt them...
Not that soon.  But it could happen later in 2018.

Yes, but the changes will only be temporary. The new Democratic Senate and House of Representatives will change those rules back to the way they were but as of January 1, 2018, they won't be sworn in yet.
Increased due to Republicans losing a senate seat and wanting to pass the tax bill sooner than later.
The Republicans understand that whatever they change now they might have to live with when the pendulum swings (as it always does) back to a Democratic controlled Senate.

time
do not need supermajority
on tax and spending measures
Too much to do in too little time.
Bumping it back up due to the tax bill negotiations putting pressure on abandoning it.
Backing off but not completely due to ambitious legislative schedule plus debt ceiling deadline.

Was stupid to have it by crazy eyes Bachmann and gay porn-Twitter liker Ted Cruz a few years ago just because they didn't like the colour of the president's skin. So it's unlikely they'll stop doing it again. Prepare for another lame reading of Dr Suess. Maybe Roy Moore will read Lolita.

They are probably already sorry for the existing provisions, because the majority party will have to bear full blame for anything stupid the body does.  Personally, I think this is right and just, but the poor babies are just not accustomed to that level of accountability.  They will not wish to test the limits any more for a while.
Looks like McConnell will stiffen his last quarter-inch of remaining spine to prevent this.  Stay tuned.

It view this as unlikely, because it is not in the interest of the governing Republican Party. 
To occur:: 
1) There must be a major bill for which the Republican leadership has 51 votes, but not 60
2) The bill cannot be passed by reconciliation, which does a similar thing, but does not require the nuclear option. 
3) Enough Republican Senators must view the issue as important enough. Senators such as McCain, Murkowski, or Collins must support the proposal.  I don't think these conditions will be met, because Step 1 is unlikely. Currently, the major bill being discussed, tax reform, only requires 51 votes under reconciliation. The leadership does not have the 51 votes, so using a nuclear option is pointless. Furthermore, Leadership is wary of breaking the filibuster rules, because the Democrats may be in power soon.  In conclusion, I find the likelihood for reducing the scope in the US in the Senate unlikely.
They have to be aware that party control changes and if they eliminate the filibuster they jeopardize their influence some point down the road.
It's politically advantageous to the R's in power

I had thought this might happen to ease the passage of the Tax Bill, but now it looks like the theater has laid out a course doomed to fail, from which the party wil blame the other and use that as justification a change - but not till the new congress is seated which is proper order for such a rule change.
Based on general news and GJP consensus.
Based on general news and GJP consensus.
Budget reconciliation set for tax bill.
Depends on if they get budget passed this year.  If doesn't Rep's will be desperate since mid-terms could suffer if nothing gets enacted.
Senate can't get out of its own way to accomplish anything.

Despite extraordinary pressure by the President, the Majority will not acquiesce and further change the rules.  Senate Leadership will be tempted, but will develop a backbone when they realize they are an equal branch of government.
Based on general news and GJP consensus.

Decreasing because of decreased time left before end of year and many other issues on the legislative agenda.  However, leaving a non-zero probability because 
1) Trump keeps pressuring Republicans on the issue: 
https://www.forbes.com/sites/randalllane/2017/10/10/trump-unfiltered/#f2112017a58f 2) There are upcoming conservative issues that are important to Trump that will only pass if the filibuster is removed:
https://www.conservativereview.com/articles/how-fixing-the-filibuster-could-save-countless-unborn-lives 3) [Bannon will] support only candidates who agree to two conditions: They will vote against McConnell as majority leader, and they will vote to end senators’ ability to block legislation by filibustering.
http://nymag.com/daily/intelligencer/2017/10/steve-bannons-dubious-plan-to-purge-senate-republicans.html
It doesn’t air sense to do that with 2018 looming as a year that can devastate the.

From @Anneinak (https://www.gjopen.com/comments/comments/593574): This is from an Admin. Please upvote it so that it appears at the top of the feed tomorrow. Thanks @Anneinak. from @amory10
Thank you [@cmeinel] for passing this along. It turns out that on September 21, a superforecaster (Bruno Jahn) went on a popular German TV show and talked about GJ Open. We were flooded with traffic and forecasts, especially on The Monkey Cage challenge because it was linked to a tutorial for new users that walks them through forecasting on a question. In other words, I too thought it was bots…but it was just Germans! :) I will stay vigilant because the threat of bots is real and worth watching out for… please do let me know if you notice other suspicious activity. And thanks again for your email.
updating for the passage of time.
+2 just because the consensus is so high and I fear I am missing something.

Basically I think it's unlikely. I think that I and other people may underestimate the probability because of wishful thinking. For this to happen, I think several things would have to happen: 
1) some piece of legislation like debt ceiling or the tax bill that is seen as mission-critical for the majority would have to be in serious jeopardy: 80%
2) Some external emergency/factor (e.g. Trump or a catastrophe) would weigh in and provide strong external force that provides members with air cover: 20%
3) They would have to be able to get a majority to support it: 20%
So I'm guess 80% x 20% x 20% = 3%
I think it's going to happen, but not before January 1st.
Highly unlikely to adopt sucha change with the current state of flux - it only made sense if R majority looked to last long.
Slight increase until legislative agenda for Fall plays out more

There is no legislation in the works that would tempt the GOP to go down this route. Health care has been significantly more difficult than they anticipated, with them unable to get 51 votes (which is what getting rid of the filibuster would do for normal legislation), and on the eve of failing to reach 51 again. Tax reform is even messier, with the only thing the GOP can agree on is tax cuts for the rich. However, reaching 51 votes on comprehensive legislation is not realistic at this point. The GOP is learning that its easy to be the party of "no" when you're the minority, but it's harder to be the party of "yes" when you're actually governing.
I don't think they will go there yet. Not this year. Going into the spring and 2018elections may be a different story.
No idea. My English skills are pretty bad.

The seconding of Trump's call for ending the filibuster comes from the House, not the Senate: http://www.cnn.com/2017/09/13/politics/kevin-mccarthy-filibuster-plan/index.html Most important passage from the article: "Earlier this year, more than half of the Senate Republican conference signed a letter stating that they did not support changing the filibuster rules for legislation. McConnell did deploy the so-called "nuclear option" allowing a simple majority vote for judicial nominees, ahead of a vote on then-Supreme Court nominee Neil Gorsuch. That followed a similar move in 2013 when Senate Democrats first used the nuclear option to make it easier to confirm then-President Barack Obama's executive and judicial appointments, except those to the Supreme Court." So it appears so far, anyway, that the Republicans don't have the votes to change the rules and do away with the filibuster altogether, and in the one instance where they did change the rules to end it, they had an indirect precedent set by the Democrats. It's very unlikely that the Republicans would take such a drastic step unless under extreme duress.
The Republik want to change many and so it is easier for them.
Majority of Republicans in both Senate and Congress.
This is one of DT's biggest points. I think he'll whip them to stop the filibusters more and more.
To go on it doesnt really matter
Changes like that would take a long time.
It is a given. Anything the (R)'s can do to remove the (D)'s obstructionist TTPs will be removed.
Republicans need to move on the political agenda, so the filibuster has to go.
Not likely.  This would cause chaos
Based on general news and GJP consensus.
Mitch McConnell will drag his feet before doing this, and the President is losing credibility with Republican leaders so he can't pressure them as much.

No way. If they change the rules now, everything they get done afterwards will be considered illegitimate. Plus, the Dem's will use the new rule to their favor if they take back the Senate next year, which they just might now that gerrymandering has become a bigger topic.
There is no reason for Senator McConnell to make this change. The president's sudden affection for "Chuck and Nancy" was the nail in the coffin.

https://www.nytimes.com/2017/09/12/us/politics/trump-tax-code-republicans-votes.html?emc=edit_th_20170913&nl=todaysheadlines&nlid=77825025 "Steven Mnuchin, the Treasury secretary, said on Tuesday that Republicans would use a parliamentary tool called reconciliation to bypass a filibuster in the Senate if Democrats refuse to get on board.  “If we can’t get 60 votes, we’re prepared to use reconciliation to get it done,” Mr. Mnuchin said at a CNBC conference.
~~~~~~~
COMMENT:  The filibuster is rarely used anymore because of reconciliation.

Votes to change senate rules are passed by a majority - thus with 52 senators R's can only lose 2 votes. Who is likely to vote against?  McCain is almost guaranteed, and Flake, Collins, Graham all seem independent of Trump enough to vote against this. Other senators are likely to join them as well. No indication McConnell wants it to happen either.  Trump is the main one pushing this, but nobody seems to be listening to him.  Democrats are being careful to stay organized and not do anything to give R's a good reason to remove the rule.  I'll give a 5% chance because that could change, or various other doomsday scenarios could happen that lead to the removal of the filibuster.  But unless there's a big shift somewhere, assume the status quo stays.
Both sides value the filibuster in worst case scenarios

Distinguished Majority Leader Yertle the Turtle and his adherents are becoming less afraid of M. Petits-Doigts every day, so they aren't going to feel any need to change this rule to accommodate his constantly shifting priorities.
Based on general news and GJP consensus.

@Anneinak Thank you for the info!  Most everything I read agrees with your points.  However, with elections coming up in 2018 and a lot of crucial votes (debt ceiling, tax reform, budgets/CRs, etc) happening this fall in Congress, there is a some chance that the politics of filibuster limitation could  change depending on how those fall votes go.  Am reducing my prob slightly, however!

I think that McConnell is up against the wall, and that Trump has painted him as a do-nothing leader of the Senate.  There's still some uncertainty; the GOP is eating its own, and may well choose legislative defeat rather than support POTUS.
No contenious issue would benefit by this that has enough support to even get to 50%

The date seems too soon.  I don't discount the real possibility it happens in Trump's first term in an effort to pass some piece of either major tax reform or infrastructure legislation.  But the Senate is drifting away from Trump at present, not towards him.  Taking a dramatic step designed fundamentally to align themselves with Trump seems unlikely in the short term.  Medium to long term is another matter.

Again, for those who've missed some earlier posts, there is no legislation in the works over which McConnell would enact this option. Health care and tax reform are being pursued through reconciliation, which only requires 51 votes. And given health care's epic failure, even reaching 51 will be difficult for a GOP trying to reconcile the future of the party. So removing the filibuster doesn't help the GOP to achieve its major legislative agenda at this point. Could it allow them to pass more substantive legislation that isn't constrained by reconciliation rules? Yes, it could, but it would also increase the scope of any piece of major legislation, bogging down the process while the GOP reconciles its position.  If the GOP was serious about passing legislation, it would reconsider its ban on earmarks before eliminating the filibuster. Right now, House and Senate members have little incentive to compromise and vote for issues that don't directly benefit their constituents or align directly with their beliefs. Removing the filibuster doesn't solve that issue.
Pressure on Mitch from Trump. Also Joe Manchin replacement is likely to happen and will be a Republican giving them 53 votes and a McCain proof majority
It is in the interest of both parties to keep the filibuster for blocking confirmation of Supreme Court justices.
At some point, the Democrats will overplay their hand, and the Senate will do what Reid/Schumer planned to do if his favored candidate had won.

Because both parties know that power shifts back and fort so will want to keep the filibuster so they can use it when needed. This was not much of a factor in the supreme court because they are appointed for life.
Both dides benefit a lot from filibustering.

I think this is a step too far for most people in the Senate, regardless of political alignment. They all know that if they change the rules today so they can jam through legislation, it's going to come back and bite them tomorrow when they're not in charge. Already Dems regret changing the rules back in 2014.
While it may seem the sweeping majority controls the house, senate and White house; there is to much old blood that still favors keeping the old ways intact.
The filibuster is very much an integral part of the Senate rules. I don't think Republicans would want to change it. Dems would, but they aren't in power.
This would let the senate not have to use reconciliation on the Health Care Bill and possibly Tax reform.

Not with McYertle as majority leader. As much as I'd like to see it gone, it isn't going to happen. The senate would rather convince itself there's a bigger majority coming next time rather than actually doing anything.
Possibly some time before 2020, but not in the time frame given.
Republicans are aligning with Trump despite his terrible agenda and performance for partisan reasons. Period.

This is something Trump wants, but there's no signal I can see that Senate Republicans would want this. Amending for Supreme Court nominations makes sense because there's a long timeline between now and the next vacant seat in the SC. With '18 elections coming up, I see this expansion staying off the table.

This has been an absolute goal of the Republican Party and its owners for decades now.  I do believe it will push very hard to ensure domination. 
The only hesitation that may waylaid its progress to have complete free reign is that it might not want to appear to be 'unfair'.  I would venture to guess it would be certain that it might rather backdoor this by making it even odds and then concentrating on gerrymandering and ensuring voters voices can be ignored. 
This is also why there are many states who have petitioned to take away amendment rights about protesting protections. 
 It seems likely that the leaks which show people within the party paying for people to disrupt and cause havoc at peaceful protests are genuine.  That way they can fan flames of outrage which they created to get what they wanted. It's a win-win.

Senate Rs are staring straight into the abyss of a D majority after the '18 elections, thanks to the unparalleled leadership of Yertle the Turtle and the Twit King.  They will not wish to monkey about with this provision any more than they already have.  (In case you were wondering, "unparalleled" is not meant as a compliment.)
Dangerous move for both parties... but not using it by republicans now doesn't insure that dems won't use it later so maybe they go there in desperation
Based on general news and GJP consensus.

There is no new major legislation that would even be eligible to filibuster. BCRA uses reconciliation and only requires 51 votes. Tax reform will be pursued through reconciliation (hence why they haven't started it, only one reconciliation bill is allowed at a time) and will only require 51 votes. The budget could be filibustered, but no one is really itching for a shutdown (save for WH), and besides, we'll be on a CR through Dec 8 at the earliest. Debt ceiling could be filibustered, but it has bipartisan support and can likely get over the 60 vote bar. With nothing significant enough to remove the legislative filibuster, there is 0 incentive for McConnell to do so, hence 0% of it happening. And for those who would argue that they could draft new major legislation that could be filibustered, I counter with the fact it would require putting tax reform, which is almost unanimously supported by the GOP, on the back burner for some new initiative. I argue that's a low probability occurrence given the trend of removing legislation by this Congress.
This congress has expanded it for the purpose of allowing the vote on Gorsuch. There are several bills that may need to be voted on within the next five months. This might happen
I think it's going to happen, but probably not until next year.

Both parties understand the profound and lasting effect that a party with power unchecked by the minority could have when it comes to lawmaking.   McConnell is a highly experienced tactical lawmaker who would recognize the severe risks and thus take all necessary steps to avoid trying to remove the filibuster rule in advance of a very volatile mid-term election cycle.

There are no major pieces of legislation in the works that would require passage through normal legislative processes. Health care and tax reform are both under reconciliation, requiring a simple majority. The inability of the WH and Congress to pass these pieces is more a reflection of the internecine warfare being waged within the GOP than anything the Dems are doing. If anything, this discord should reemphasize to McConnell the GOP need for a legislative filibuster, as the Dems traditionally pass larger entitlement-based programs that would be nearly impossible to undo if the Dems took control of the WH and both chambers. When the GOP can finally figure out how to pass legislation, and pass it through normal legislative processes (not reconciliation), I'll revise. But as of now, there is nothing being brought to the floor to which eliminating the filibuster is even worth considering.
The Senate healthcare bill hasn't been passed by the Fourth of July deadline McConnell set, so there's a greater likelihood that McConnell will change the rules to get what he wants.
Less and less of a possibility. I'm thinking Republican leadership privately see losses to come in 2018, and wouldn't want to hand the Dems any tools to use against them.

The R Senators, jointly and severally, appear to be much less eager to kowtow to M. Petits-Doigts than they were scant weeks ago.  However, they can't afford to look like they're throwing him off the sleigh to the wolves because his base will lay down their remotes, lurch up from their couches, and start voting in primaries for even more hopeless bozos than the incumbents.  Kind makes you proud to be an amurrican, huh?  Now imagine how those of us feel who still identify as Republicans...

Something to think about regarding how "the scope of matters for which a filibuster cannot be used" is interpreted. If budget reconciliation rules are violated and the Parliamentarian is overruled, then non-budget items such as anti-abortion language could be retained in the healthcare bill. This would expand the scope of issues where a filibuster can't be used however, I'm not sure whether that would satisfy this question.   http://nymag.com/daily/intelligencer/2017/06/the-right-to-life-lobby-is-not-in-a-mood-for-compromise.html The reference to “procedural” problems is an allusion to widespread reports that the Senate parliamentarian has ruled the language restricting use of tax credits as non-germane to the budget, which might mean it must be taken out of the bill lest it lose its status as a “budget reconciliation” measure that needs only 51 votes to pass. As the Breitbart piece goes on to explain, the RTLers want the Senate to overrule the parliamentarian on this point —which it can, but at the risk of opening the floodgates to other non-germane amendments, like the changes in Obamacare regulations so many conservatives want. Eventually, pushing aside the special Senate rules for consideration of the budget could amount to a backdoor abolition of the legislative filibuster, as senators seek to push every controversial piece of legislation imaginable into budget bills that cannot be filibustered. That is a precedent Mitch McConnell would be reluctant to set. http://www.washingtonexaminer.com/gop-senators-parliamentarian-says-anti-abortion-language-in-healthcare-bill-violates-senate-rules/article/2626669#
An effort to tie abortion restrictions to tax credits in a healthcare bill doesn't meet Senate rules according to the chamber's parlimentarian, two senators said on Wednesday. Sen. Susan Collins, R-Maine, told reporters Wednesday she believes the tax credits didn't meet the rules for reconciliation, which is the process by which Republicans are using to try to pass a healthcare bill with a simple majority to avoid a Democratic filibuster. Sen. Thom Tillis, R-N.C. said the same. "I believe that did not pass through the parliamentarian's review so I don't expect that," Collins told reporters. Tillis indicated that Republicans were looking at other ways to include anti-abortion language in the bill.
"It would not be in the direct sense it was proposed in the House, but I think there are ways to address most of the concerns of members," he said. If the senators are right about the judgment by the senate parliamentarian (which was not yet confirmed by leadership), it would complicate efforts by Republicans to craft a healthcare compromise that satisfies all of the party's ideological factions. The House-passed bill created a new set of tax credits for individuals to purchase insurance that included Hyde Amendment language, a spending rider that prohibits federal funding from going towards abortions. If that is no longer allowed, it means that in order to include anti-abortion language that will be crucial to securing the votes of conservatives, Senate drafters will have to come up with a new way to introduce their tax credits, most likely by running them through an existing program that already includes Hyde language, or by tweaking the tax credits in Obamacare itself.
Still unlikely, for the reasons I gave previously. He's starting to see the downside of winning at all cost: winning doesn't give you legitimacy. The mandate of the popular vote does.
Leadership unlikely to take such a dramatic step. Many Rs privately believe 2018 and 2020 election cycles will favor Ds

http://thehill.com/blogs/pundits-blog/economy-budget/339451-funeral-for-the-filibuster-gop-may-lay-senate-tool-to-rest (Opinion) The legislative filibuster is dead; it is a fait accompli. The Republican majority has already gutted what remained of the judicial filibuster, and now both President Trump, via Twitter, and Senate Majority Leader McConnell (R-Ky.) are floating the idea of nuking the legislative filibuster. 

Both leaders are currently contemplating moving forward without the legislative filibuster because it is becoming more and more clear that the only viable path to pass both the American Health Care Act (AHCA) and tax reform is through a simple majority legislative process without restrictions on adding to the deficit.

Congressional Republicans have been attempting to use the traditional legislative tool to pass legislation via a simple majority — reconciliation. Budget reconciliation is the fast-track process that allows tax cuts — and would allow the AHCA — to pass the Senate with the simple majority that the Republicans currently have. Comment: considering that there are many fewer than 50 Senate Republicans in favor of this (supposedly less mean) version of healthcare reform, how would eliminating the filibuster help? And in the long run, it may hurt Republicans more than Dems. This is the only tool that gives them more power compared to the House.
They might be fearing a return to Democratic majorities in the next election or two.

Yesterday, I gave this a 70 percent likelihood, but I'm going to adjust it downward to 55 percent (which may still be a little high-ish), because even though I am convinced there is about an 85 percent likelihood Trump will inform McConnell that it's time to deploy the so-called "nuclear option" during the first two years of his Presidency, it's not at all certain that event isn't significant;y more likely to occur in 2018, as opposed to what remains of 2017.  I really wish the question were framed in that manner ie., "Before 1 January 2019."  Then I would feel much more confident about my answer.  The calendar year is largely irrelevant here, as compared to the semi-annual cycle of national elections.  But there is a history of very little legislation getting passed during national election years (such as 2018), so the "nuke" may well be dropped some time around, oh, I'd say September, if the proverbial pistol were at my head. Most people seem to think the "nuclear option" is very unlikely (or maybe they just think 2017 isn't the year it will be used?), but I see no other way for Trump to get any signature legislation passed (other than for the slim possibility he can get 60 votes in favor of his infrastructure bill).  2017 & 2018 are the only two years he can be CERTAIN his party will control both Houses of Congress, so he will seek to advance some legislation through the chambers during this period.  And he's already shown a willingness to expand beyond Obama's 2013 breach of the filibuster.
Lowered by 50%. No need to change rules with R's controlling all 3 branches of govt.

McConnell has set a precedent that he doesn't really care about Senate tradition. He did it with the Supreme Court nomination and he is willing to put a major legislation on the floor without committee hearings (the healthcare bill). In the case that the healthcare bill doesn't get passed by July 4th like he wants it to, he very much might move towards to expanding the scope of matters for which a filibuster cannot be used.

Back down to 0. Republicans are pursuing reconciliation route for health care and tax reform (https://www.washingtonpost.com/news/politics/wp/2017/06/19/senate-leaders-plan-to-rush-a-health-care-bill-to-a-vote-and-theres-nothing-democrats-can-do-about-it/?utm_term=.482c86052d41) McConnell (old but still good): “There is not a single senator from the majority who thinks we ought to change the legislative filibuster" (https://www.nytimes.com/2017/04/05/us/politics/filibuster-gorsuch-nomination-republicans.html?_r=1)
They would do this at their own peril. I don't see what they would do this for.  There is no advantage to allowing that to happen.
It wouldn't serve the republicans now or possibly in the future if they did away with it.

Mitch McConnell is looking to get a vote on the Senate healthcare bill before senators on the fence go home to face opposition in town hall meetings during the July 4th recess.  A few high-profile senators on both sides of the aisle are warning against moving so quickly to get a half-cooked bill on the floor (https://www.bloomberg.com/politics/articles/2017-06-18/sanders-signals-backing-of-senate-slowdown-over-health-care-bill).  Raising from 0% to a semi-symbolic 1% in case McConnell feels he won't have the votes after the recess, but if there's anyone who understands how to play the long game and hedge their bets it's him, and such hot-headed action would only hurt him and the Republican party in the long run.
Pre midterm push to end Democrat obstruction

Majority Leader Yertle the Turtle has said No to this.   The Senate Rs are keenly aware that they will not be in the majority forever--unlike the pathetic little man in the White House, who is not keenly aware of anything except whatever Fox News tells him about the level of his adulation and whatever his kids tell him about the level of his money.  He will insist on this change, using his customary Twit And Shout method, but to no avail.  Some day he may learn that the members of Congress are not his personal employees and he can't fire them, so he has to work with them instead.  Do not bet on any conclusion for which a premise is that he will learn something, though.
No need to ditch filibuster for legistration at this moment.

The Senate Majority leader is in his childhood dream job and he is very cognizant of the history of his position. He felt forced to change the filibuster for the confirmation of Justices of the Supreme Court and thinks he may now need only to threaten to expand fillibuster changes to help push his party's agenda. He doesn't want to go down in history for changing anymore historic rules in concern to the fillibuster.

The number of bills that are in the conservative wish list, repeal of Dodd-Frank, re-arranging social programs, environmental de-regulation will be blocked by the Democrats staying united.  The need for 60 votes for cloture will stifle almost any agreement.
if the Republicans feel this tactic is no longer useful to them they will axe it.

Unlikely. While Mitch McConnell did move to chance the rules for confirming Gorsuch, he knows that when the Dems eventually retake the senate, the GOP will struggle under the same new rules. Further, if they did it again, the Dems will paint the GOP as nothing but hypocrites and cheaters. Once is enough. Twice is pushing it. Then again, we are in a post-reason world now. McConnell could decide to retire and leave it to the next guys to deal with.

Several prominent Republican senators, McConnell, Cornryn, McCain, and others have come out strongly against nuking the legislative filibuster.  They note that it can be very frustrating in the short term to not be able to get to 60 votes, but in the long term it prevents bad policy from being approved in the Senate.  Moreover, even if McConnell flipped flops on his strong stance against nuking it, 28 Republican and 33 Democratic senators signed a letter to the majority and minority leaders against it. I have a very difficult time going higher than 90% against in a prediction like this, but since there are only 7 months left in this year, and Republicans will likely hold the Senate majority in 2018 (especially with vice presidential tiebreaker), I think something extreme would need to happen to become desperate enough to do this in 2017. McConnell:
http://www.politico.com/story/2017/04/mitch-mcconnell-promises-not-to-kill-filibuster-236873 Letter:
http://nymag.com/daily/intelligencer/2017/05/trump-lobbies-on-twitter-to-eliminate-legislative-filibuster.html Senate Majority in 2018:
https://fivethirtyeight.com/features/nuking-the-filibuster-may-hurt-republicans-in-the-long-run/
Not changing % probability but note Pres. Trumps call on Sen. McConnell to end filibuster.

Downgrade to 0. Despite Trump's tweeting, the Senate Republicans are already pursuing health care and tax reform through reconciliation, which only requires a simple majority. Beyond those two items, the GOP has no major legislation coming to the floor in either chamber. Nothing. Which means there is nothing even worth considering removing the filibuster for.  I think the Republicans and McConnell would have pursued removing the filibuster if there was some legislation so significant that it would change the American political landscape (in their favor) for the next generation. But there's not. There's not even a clear path forward for the GOP agenda. So there's no point going nuclear when you don't even have a battle to fight. The Senate calendar for the rest of CY17 looks like this: spend the next two months figuring out how to dispose of the toxic AHCA bill the House dumped at their doorstep, go through a highly televised and scrutinized FBI director confirmation (whenever Trump nominates someone), negotiate a bipartisan budget deal to ease the BCA caps and avoid sequestration, pass an FY18 CR through December 2018, negotiate an FY18 budget agreement (different than the budget deal) and reconciliation procedures for FY18, raise the debt ceiling, pass an FY18 Appropriation (or suffer through another CR and the accompanying questions of their ability to govern), figure out if FY17 reconciliation efforts for health care can carry forward into FY18, and then find some legislative win, any win really (since the big ticket items are not likely to happen), to show for their first 12 months of governance. Nothing in that provides a reason for going nuclear.

McConnell is an institutionalist, meaning that he's unlikely to be on board with further expanding the filibuster. Furthermore, the Republicans have a low majority and I think enough members will defect for them not to get enough support for a rule change.

There is virtually no chance of this happening, despite Trump's dreams to the contrary. Senate Majority Leader McConnell does not support this at all. After all, it was only a few years ago that the Democrats controlled the Senate, the House, and the Presidency. If not for the 60 vote requirement, Conservatives would not have been able to halt the legislative progress and win back seats by being the "Party of No." McConnell knows very well that his position could very well be reversed in a few years.

Increasing probability after Trump tweet this morning.  
http://www.zerohedge.com/news/2017-05-30/trump-calls-senate-nuclear-option-avoid-shutdown-claims-dems-would-do-it The senate might not want to do it, but they also can't pass any legislation as broadcast on the front of the WSJ this morning.  Ouch.: 
https://www.wsj.com/articles/gops-proposed-tax-changes-are-no-match-for-status-quo-1496055605
McConnell won't budge on this. I am (86%) certain!
Trump Calls For Senate 'Nuclear Option' To Avoid Shutdown, Claims "Dems Would Do It"

I doubt it.  Even though it is possible to play that kind of brinkmanship, over a longer-term this could lead to a very volatile way of politics.  Things could be reinstated once a majority changes.  I think that this really was a "nuclear option", because the SCOTUS position can not be taken away.  As for other legislature, it could potentially hurt republicans when the Senate becomes a Democratic majority.  I think that Republicans will not want to be completely shut out of the game.

I find it extremely unlikely that Senate Republicans will do this, given that they do not share a universal approach to issues such as health care reform, tax policy, trade, etc. Moderate Conservatives are very mindful of the possibility that it may be in their best political interests NOT to vote along party lines on controversial subjects. With the President's tepid approval ratings, Conservatives must be mindful that in the next several years, they may suddenly find themselves back in the minority and need the filibuster once again.

Although McConnell has stated his opposition to removal of the filibuster, there seems to be a growing interest among other senators (today in politico).  Still unlikely, but in these crazy times, odds have increased.

The verbiage the Republicans used when referring to the Affordable Healthcare Act as Obamacare has put many of their seats at risk.  The constituencies of some Republican US Senators benefit hugely from the Affordable Healthcare Act.  There are 8 Republican incumbents likely running for US Senate in 2018.  If the Republicans lose 2 of those seats, Democrats take them and hold their current seats, the US Senate belongs to the swing votes of Independents on many issues.  If the Republicans change the filibuster rules, they would put themselves in a precarious position because their changes could have unforeseen consequences for their party.  I predict the US Senate will not change filibuster rules before the first of next year.
Not many vulnerable seats in 2018, but a few big topics to address. Healthcare seems likely to cause problems. If polls shift, we're not going to see Senate Republicans taking this kind of risk.
The cooperation between the Democrats and Republicans is unprecedented compared to recent history

I only envision Senate Republicans blocking filibusters to confirm other federal judges (not Supreme Court), not for legislation or any other purpose. I do not know whether that will be considered an "expansion" under this question.
The controlling party can see the situation turn into a bad situation in 2020 because who they will be running in that election.

Removing the first filibuster was simple enough and highly supported by those that elected Trump. Removing the second filibuster would cripple the balance of power. Republicans would not do that so early in Trump's term. Maybe on year 3 if he has a strong approval rating and high probablility of 4 more years.
Just following the more active forecasters.

As the administration continues destroying everything it touches, the Congressional Republicans will need to choose either to divest its support of Trump, or push through a major legislative achievement. It's unclear as to whether Congress can continue pursuing AHCA under FY17 reconciliation procedures after October 1. With the weekly crisis coming out of 1600 Pennsylvania, Congress has to focus efforts they would otherwise spend on getting AHCA through. They could attempt to pass major tax reform under FY18 reconciliation procedures, but that likely pushes that legislation into CY18. Any other major piece of legislation, would require bipartisan support to get through the Senate, or elimination of the filibuster.  Oh, and in case you think there's not an emphasis to get a major achievement, keep in mind that no discussions of a bipartisan budget deal have started, meaning that FY18 will start with a CR at best, and sequestration at worst. It's not exactly a shining example of your ability to govern when you can't even negotiate raising spending caps, which is generally favored by both parties. I know, McConnell has said he won't go nuclear on the legislative filibuster. And while he may come across as convincing, he's also savvy enough to recognize the very real possibility of losing either chamber if they alienate their voters by failing to achieve anything significant. And while 6 months seems like a long time to get something significant passed, the Senate has 102 legislative days left, and the House has 88. And in that time, they have to, collectively, pass AHCA, start tax reform, negotiate a bipartisan budget deal, raise the debt ceiling, pass FY18 appropriations (or a CR), and confirm the slow trickle of PAS positions as the WH gets around to filling them. Not a lot of time to score a win without taking some drastic measures...
McConnell has made it known that he has zero inclination to further reduce the filibuster.  This is a very low probability but will bear watching.

It's short-sided for the GOP to ban their own weapons.. Not only would it screw them when they lose the majority, they'll have to put up with at least a week of pundits hammering them on the history and traditions of congress while running endless clips of Mr. Smith Goes to Washington.

The rebuplicans realize they were playing with fire doing what they did with the filibuster. Given the key topics that will be addressed through year's end (health care, travel ban, and budget). The filibuster to block legislation will remain. To avoid any more precedents being set, the Democrats will now try to run midterm elections on new Republican policies and laws versus pushing filibusters to their eventual limit.

There is currently a complicated path to get both health care and tax reform done this year via the reconciliation process: https://www.vox.com/policy-and-politics/2017/5/2/15515216/republicans-health-bill-rush . Senators like the cover the filibuster provides and know that they will be on the minority side in the future: http://thehill.com/blogs/pundits-blog/economy-budget/332058-senators-on-both-sides-are-friends-of-the-filibuster. Leaving a 5% chance that Trump gets upset that passing the tax bill is taking too long and successfully pressures senate republican leaders into trying to remove the filibuster.  This can absolutely be done pretty easily with a majority vote.

The Republican leadership in the Senate does not appear to want to eliminate the filibuster in any other way.  There may be pressure from the White House to do so, however,  I do not see it successfully moving the Senate any farther on the issue.

Unless the Republicans want to pass a comprehensive tax reform bill instead of using reconciliation, there aren't any major pieces of legislation worth going nuclear over. With that said, I still don't fully trust what Senate R leadership says. Instead, I'll wait for some action by them indicating they'll stand up to the WH.
Revising down after looking at consensus. Not sure about justifications, but I don't have a strong reason to forecast with high certainty.

Reasons for No:
The power to filibuster is the primary distinction between the House of Representatives and the Senate 
Removing the filibuster would make Senators less powerful, more common and more controlled by the majority leader regardless of which party is in power
McConnell may want to keep the filibuster as a tool that could help him protect Republicans up for election from having to vote on issues that may hurt them Blaming the Democrats for obstruction is a tool he likes to use, and without the filibuster, he loses that along with excuses for not producing Trump is pressuring McConnell on this issue as Congress continues to prove unable to move the Republican agenda. Trump saw this happen on the budget where Democrats prevented funding for the Wall and funded Obamacare, Planned Parenthood and other Dem priorities instead. He is now favoring a government shutdown for “next time.” If things start moving out of the House which is tough enough, McConnell will get increasing pressure from Trump to do this. I assume that McConnell is a pragmatist who after being a US Senator for 34 years has learned to bide his time. He understands that Trump is more anxious for a victory but that he needs to shore up his majority in 2018.  Apparently, he has decided to get involved in the selection of the candidates for these elections.  So, if there is a probability of getting rid of the filibuster, I don’t think it is a strong one within the specified time frame.

The President wants this badly.  Yertle, the Distinguished Turtle from Kentucky and Senate Majority Leader, is quoted today as saying nobody except the President wants it.  The President has zero votes in the Senate; he is likely outraged by this fact, as he is by most facts.
I think the GOP has more foresight than to remove the filibuster at this time.

it is one thing to do this on an "advise and consent" function, but for legislation they wont remove it; way too much backlash and they are not stupid enough to think they will never need it when they lose power.
I strongly suspect that the need will arise for more legislation to be passed in order to appear successful.
A large number of Senators are attached to the filibuster
If it's one of Trump's major promises, I imagine it will occur again since it was so easy with the Supreme Court
The Senate found it very easy to do recently regarding the SCOTUS appointment.   They will do it again.
It's been eliminated once already, one more time doesn't matter.
I agree with Walt that this will depend on an important enough bill being at stake. If it is one of Trumps big promises then he may apply a lot pressure to see it happen.

Trump and Congressional GOP will be desperate to pass legislation. They can blame the Dems for awhile but will probably eventually decide to just kill the filibuster. They won't worry about future repercussions (i.e., losing the ability to filibuster in the future if they lose their majority) because they have a stranglehold on a majority of state legislatures, where they can continue to enact voter suppression laws.

This is entirely up to Mitch McConnell. This is a matter of changing Senate rules and only the majority leader has the authority to bring that issue to the floor. He will not hesitate to change the rules, but to do it he needs 51 Republican votes. To get those, he needs a big enough issue to make it all worthwhile since eliminating the filibuster could backfire. There is no such issue in the pipeline. Healthcare isn't it: if anything ever comes out of the House, it will be some unlovable mutant that will likely be suffocated in conference so that no Senator has to vote on it publicly. The budget might be it, but that has to start in the House. Even then, McConnell has the option of doing some reconciliation magic to get it through on 51 votes. Wait on this one to see where we are in September. Tax reform might be it, but that, too, has to start in the House and Paul Ryan seems to be having trouble passing the salt, as they say, let alone something as complex as a tax reform package. Were I McConnell, I'd wait for the 2018 mid-terms. The Ds have 25 seats up of which 13 are in play to some degree. The Rs have 9 seats up of which 2 are in play. There's a better than even chance that the Rs could have a filibuster-proof 60 votes in the 116th. Why risk unforeseeable backlash for changing the rules if you can get what you want under the current rules by just holding tight for 18 months? Yes, it's a long game, but McConnell is very good at the long game.         http://www.270towin.com/2018-senate-election/
http://cookpolitical.com/senate/charts/race-ratings
Why not. It worked, and will likely be used again.

Picking a very cowardly number to start with.   In the end it will come down to whether the Rs in the Senate are more afraid of the implications or of the President.   He will start to demand this change very soon, since he has never displayed either understanding of nor patience with the concept of "implications."  The Rs will very likely cave in, sooner or later.  The cloture rule is terrible and should be killed anyway, but it will be sort of sad to see it go out this way.

While Senate R's have indicated they will not eliminate the filibuster for legislation, the truth of the matter is that both sides have set off down this course. With the administration unable to achieve much in the first 100 days, and the desire to have some substantial achievement prior to the completion of his first year in office and the subsequent State of the Union, Trump and the R's will want to push forward some major piece of legislation (whether health care or tax reform remains to be seen).  With the Senate R's only holding 52 seats, and assuming no loss of seats due to unforeseen circumstances, they will need to convince Senate D's to support their legislation. If this fails, which is fairly likely if health care remains in its current version and if tax reform disproportionately benefits the wealthy, Senate D's will attempt to block the legislation via filibuster. At that time, Senate Republican leadership will have to decide whether to go nuclear, or let the legislation, and the chance to show substantial achievement and ability to govern, be defeated. As the 1-year mark gets progressively closer, the WH will put increasing pressure on McConnell to go nuclear to pass major legislation, and he will likely be more inclined, as the legislative filibuster is already viewed as likely to be eliminated within the next few years. I go with a 65% chance right now, and that will likely increase if the WH and Congressional R's can figure out major legislation they can all agree on and move forward, especially if it takes them into the fall to reach agreement.
